document.docAuthor: Ferro, Gustavo Borges & Marshall, Stephen A.
document.docTitle: Paragrallomyia pseudoalbibasis Ferro & Marshall 2020, new species
document.masterDocTitle: A redefinition of Paragrallomyia Hendel (Diptera: Micropezidae, Taeniapterinae) and a revision of the P. albibasis complex

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A redefinition of Paragrallomyia Hendel (Diptera: Micropezidae, Taeniapterinae) and a revision of the P. albibasis complex

mods:name.mods:affiliation: School of Environmental Sciences, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON, Canada, N 1 G 2 W 1. & bferrog @ gmail. com; https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0003 - 2091 - 0872
School of Environmental Sciences, University of Guelph, Guelph, ON, Canada, N 1 G 2 W 1. & samarsha @ uoguelph. ca; https: // orcid. org / 0000 - 0002 - 5732 - 9718

subSubSection.paragraph: Description: Body length 7 mm ; wing 5 mm . Head and abdomen dark brown, thorax black. Palpus dark brown except for white outer face. Clypeus dark brown with sparse pale microsetulae. First flagellomere dark brown. Fronto-orbital plate dark brown. Row of katepisternal setae brownish. Fore tibia dark brown. Fore tarsus mostly white, tarsomere one brown on basal half only. Hind femur mostly brown, white on basal quarter and with a small angled preapical white ring. Tergites dark brown. Oviscape dark brown.

Thorax: Mesonotum with lines of thin brownish microsetulae. Anterior half of postpronotal lobe bare. Femur covered with sparse black microsetulae. Mid and hind tibia flattened, sulcus on outer face strongly pronounced and curved ( Fig. 37 ). Female cervical sclerite with a white oval swollen on posterior end. Cell r 4+5 open at the tip of the wing.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 35–38.
Paragrallomyia pseudoalbibasis
n. sp.
35, female, dorsal view; 36, female internal reproductive structures, lateral view; 37, Costa Rica, dorsal view; 38, copulatory fork and internal reproductive structures, ventral and lateral view, respectively.

Etymology: The specific name reflects similarity with
P. albibasis
.

Comments: A very s imilar species to
P. albibasis
, however
P. pseudoalbibasis
can easily be recognized by the flattened mid and hind tibiae with the sulcus on the outer face strongly pronounced and curved. The long and thin ejaculatory apodeme blade also differs from the reduced blade of
P. albibasis
.
